summary: study included 16 patients of different clinical subtypes of psoriasis. interleukin-18 gene expression analysis was performed using real time quantitative PCR. three biopsies were obtained from each patient. interleukin (IL)-18 induces low levels of IFN-, but in the presence of costimulants, IFN- production is greatly enhanced. IL-18 suppresses the production of IL-10 and does not induce the production of IL-1R. a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in the promoter of the IL-18 gene is associated with the presence of psoriasis, but not atopic dermatitis. this suggests that the SNP is associated with the presence of psoriasis vulgaris, presumably by affecting the production of IL-18. three patients were hypertensive, 3 had psoriatic arthropathy, 1 had hepatitis C virus (HCV) with anaemia of chronic disorder type and 1 had diabetes mellitus with hypertension. a positive family history was encountered only in one case. only 5 of the studied patients were not affected by predisposing factors. patients receiving systemic methotrexate were subjected to monitoring liver blood tests monthly. eight patients with mild to moderate degrees of psoriasis were maintained on topical steroid creams and ointments in form of betamethasone dipropionate, twice daily. third psoriatic lesional skin biopsy was taken from all patients. each PCR reaction contained 1 of TaqMan universal PCR master mix. 50 nM to 900 nM of forward primer, 50 nM to 900 nM of reverse primer, 250 nM of TaqMan probe labelled with 6-carboxyfluorescein. gene expression was determined for each sample. RNA extraction and complementary (c)DNA synthesis Total RNA was extracted using QIA amp RNA extraction kit provided by QIAGEN worldwide companies. cDNAs were stored at –20°C until real-time quantitative PCR was performed. glyceraldehydes-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), a constitutively expressed housekeeping gene, was performed on all samples. all genes were subsequently normalized
